 12  /-!
 13  # Nonsingular inverses
 14  
 15  In this file, we define an inverse for square matrices of invertible
 16  determinant. For matrices that are not square or not of full rank, there is a
 17  more general notion of pseudoinverses. Unfortunately, the definition of
 18  pseudoinverses is typically in terms of inverses of nonsingular matrices, so we
 19  need to define those first. The file also doesn't define a `has_inv` instance
 20  for `matrix` so that can be used for the pseudoinverse instead.
 21  
 22  The definition of inverse used in this file is the adjugate divided by the determinant.
 23  The adjugate is calculated with Cramer's rule, which we introduce first.
 24  The vectors returned by Cramer's rule are given by the linear map `cramer`,
 25  which sends a matrix `A` and vector `b` to the vector consisting of the
 26  determinant of replacing the `i`th column of `A` with `b` at index `i`
 27  (written as `(A.update_column i b).det`).
 28  Using Cramer's rule, we can compute for each matrix `A` the matrix `adjugate A`.
 29  The entries of the adjugate are the determinants of each minor of `A`.
 30  Instead of defining a minor to be `A` with column `i` and row `j` deleted, we
 31  replace the `i`th column of `A` with the `j`th basis vector; this has the same
 32  determinant as the minor but more importantly equals Cramer's rule applied
 33  to `A` and the `j`th basis vector, simplifying the subsequent proofs.
 34  We prove the adjugate behaves like `det A • A⁻¹`. Finally, we show that dividing
 35  the adjugate by `det A` (if possible), giving a matrix `nonsing_inv A`, will
 36  result in a multiplicative inverse to `A`.
 37  
 38  ## References
 39  
 40    * https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cramer's_rule#Finding_inverse_matrix
 41

 97  section cramer
 98  /-!
 99    ### `cramer` section
100  
101    Introduce the linear map `cramer` with values defined by `cramer_map`.
102    After defining `cramer_map` and showing it is linear,
103    we will restrict our proofs to using `cramer`.
104  -/
105  variables [comm_ring α] (A : matrix n n α) (b : n → α)
id              └───────┘         └────┘
src             └───────┘         └────┘
typ             └───────┘         └────┘
106  
107  /--
108    `cramer_map A b i` is the determinant of the matrix `A` with column `i` replaced with `b`,
109    and thus `cramer_map A b` is the vector output by Cramer's rule on `A` and `b`.
110  
111    If `A ⬝ x = b` has a unique solution in `x`, `cramer_map` sends a square matrix `A`
112    and vector `b` to the vector `x` such that `A ⬝ x = b`.
113    Otherwise, the outcome of `cramer_map` is well-defined but not necessarily useful.
114  -/
115  def cramer_map (i : n) : α := (A.update_column i b).det
id                       ┴    ┴     ┴└────────────┘ ┴ ┴ └─┘
src                                  └────────────┘     └─┘
typ                      ┴    ┴     ┴└────────────┘ ┴ ┴ └─┘
doc                                  └────────────┘     └─┘
116

152  /-- The linear map of vectors associated to Cramer's rule.
153  
154    To help the elaborator, we need to make the type `α` an explicit argument to
155    `cramer`. Otherwise, the coercion `⇑(cramer A) : (n → α) → (n → α)` gives an
156    error because it fails to infer the type (even though `α` can be inferred from
157    `A : matrix n n α`).
158  -/
159  def cramer (α : Type v) [comm_ring α] (A : matrix n n α) : (n → α) →ₗ[α] (n → α) :=
id                            └───────┘ ┴       └────┘ ┴ ┴ ┴     ┴   ┴  └─┘┴┴  ┴   ┴
src                           └───────┘         └────┘                  └─┘ ┴
typ                           └───────┘ ┴       └────┘ ┴ ┴ ┴     ┴   ┴  └─┘┴┴  ┴   ┴
160  is_linear_map.mk' (cramer_map A) (cramer_is_linear A)
id   └───────────────┘  └────────┘ ┴   └──────────────┘ ┴
src  └───────────────┘  └────────┘     └──────────────┘
typ  └───────────────┘  └────────┘ ┴   └──────────────┘ ┴
doc                     └────────┘

doc                               └────┘             └────────────┘     └─┘

196  
197  section adjugate
198  /-! ### `adjugate` section
199  
200  Define the `adjugate` matrix and a few equations.
201  These will hold for any matrix over a commutative ring,
202  while the `inv` section is specifically for invertible matrices.
203  -/
204  
205  variable [comm_ring α]
id             └───────┘
src            └───────┘
typ            └───────┘
206  /-- The adjugate matrix is the transpose of the cofactor matrix.
207  
208    Typically, the cofactor matrix is defined by taking the determinant of minors,
209    i.e. the matrix with a row and column removed.
210    However, the proof of `mul_adjugate` becomes a lot easier if we define the
211    minor as replacing a column with a basis vector, since it allows us to use
212    facts about the `cramer` map.
213  -/
214  def adjugate (A : matrix n n α) : matrix n n α := λ i, cramer α A (λ j, if i = j then 1 else 0)
id                     └────┘ ┴ ┴ ┴    └────┘ ┴ ┴ ┴      ┴  └────┘ ┴ ┴    ┴     ┴ ┴ ┴
src                    └────┘          └────┘               └────┘                ┴
typ                    └────┘ ┴ ┴ ┴    └────┘ ┴ ┴ ┴      ┴  └────┘ ┴ ┴    ┴     ┴ ┴ ┴
doc                                                         └────┘
215  
216  lemma adjugate_def (A : matrix n n α) :
id                           └────┘ ┴ ┴ ┴
src                          └────┘
typ                          └────┘ ┴ ┴ ┴
217    adjugate A = λ i, cramer α A (λ j, if i = j then 1 else 0) := rfl
id     └──────┘ ┴ ┴   ┴  └────┘ ┴ ┴    ┴     ┴ ┴ ┴                   └─┘
src    └──────┘   ┴      └────┘                ┴                     └─┘
typ    └──────┘ ┴ ┴   ┴  └────┘ ┴ ┴    ┴     ┴ ┴ ┴                   └─┘
doc    └──────┘          └────┘
218  
219  lemma adjugate_val (A : matrix n n α) (i j : n) :
id                           └────┘ ┴ ┴ ┴         ┴
src                          └────┘
typ                          └────┘ ┴ ┴ ┴         ┴
220    adjugate A i j = (A.update_column j (λ j, if i = j then 1 else 0)).det := rfl
id     └──────┘ ┴ ┴ ┴ ┴  ┴└────────────┘ ┴    ┴     ┴ ┴ ┴                └─┘     └─┘
src    └──────┘       ┴   └────────────┘              ┴                  └─┘     └─┘
typ    └──────┘ ┴ ┴ ┴ ┴  ┴└────────────┘ ┴    ┴     ┴ ┴ ┴                └─┘     └─┘
doc    └──────┘           └────────────┘                                 └─┘

222  lemma adjugate_transpose (A : matrix n n α) : (adjugate A)ᵀ = adjugate (Aᵀ) :=
id                                 └────┘ ┴ ┴ ┴     └──────┘ ┴ ┴ ┴ └──────┘  ┴┴

279  section inv
280  /-! ### `inv` section
281  
282  Defines the matrix `nonsing_inv A` and proves it is the inverse matrix
283  of a square matrix `A` as long as `det A` has a multiplicative inverse.
284  -/
285  
286  variables [comm_ring α] [has_inv α]
id              └───────┘     └─────┘
src             └───────┘     └─────┘
typ             └───────┘     └─────┘
287  
288  /-- The inverse of a nonsingular matrix.
289  
290    This is not the most general possible definition, so we don't instantiate `has_inv` (yet).
291  -/
292  def nonsing_inv (A : matrix n n α) : matrix n n α := (A.det)⁻¹ • adjugate A
id                        └────┘ ┴ ┴ ┴    └────┘ ┴ ┴ ┴     ┴└──┘ └┘ ┴ └──────┘ ┴
src                       └────┘          └────┘            └──┘ └┘ ┴ └──────┘
typ                       └────┘ ┴ ┴ ┴    └────┘ ┴ ┴ ┴     ┴└──┘ └┘ ┴ └──────┘ ┴
